body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

this approach is a hack in the first place, as 0.9 doesn't support __table_args__ on the inherited class and this relies upon CheckConstraint happening to do a certain kind of autoattach (e.g. UniqueConstraint doesn't do it).

that said, the autoattach feature in 1.0 is more aggressive but to work around unnamed columns might require a lot of rearrangement.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

In 0.9, CheckConstraint has the omission of even being able to track columns, so that's why this doesn't raise in 0.9.

**Gabor Gombas wrote:**

In the real code I use `__declare_last__()` to process `__extra_table_args__`, but the error triggered even without that, so I omitted it to make the test case simpler.

**Gabor Gombas wrote:**

So what's the solution? Do I have to start passing explicit names to Column() to be able to use CheckConstraint?

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

well the immediate works-right-now solution is:

```
class VlanInterface(Interface):
    parent_id = Column(ForeignKey(Interface.id, name='iface_parent_fk'))

    __mapper_args__ = {'polymorphic_identity': 'vlan'}

CheckConstraint(or_(
    VlanInterface.parent_id != null(),
    Interface.interface_type != 'vlan'),
    name='iface_vlan_ck')

```

the very interesting way that your test case actually manages to do "auto-attach" is because *one* column *is* attached to the table already with its name, on the superclass, so it finds the table.

**Gabor Gombas wrote:**

Ok, that does not look bad, I'll try it. Thanks!

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

it will work in 0.9 and 1.0.    I'm poking around still but your test is really a much thinner edge case than it initially seems (only CheckConstraint, only on single-table inheritance subclass w/ extra column.  wont work any other way in 0.9)

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

I might "wontfix" this but let me look at it later as it isn't as urgent.   I'm sure other people are going to hit similar issues.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- The "auto-attach" feature of constraints such as :class:`.UniqueConstraint`
and :class:`.CheckConstraint` has been further enhanced such that
when the constraint is associated with non-table-bound :class:`.Column`
objects, the constraint will set up event listeners with the
columns themselves such that the constraint auto attaches at the
same time the columns are associated with the table.  This in particular
helps in some edge cases in declarative but is also of general use.
fixes #3341


â†’ bdcaa0f6ca58

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

we're going to have a lot of betas....   anyway you got it

issue.title: uniqueconstraint attachment logic fails for combination of Column + string names

labels.name: declarative
labels.description: has to do with the declarative API, scanning classes and mixins for attributes to be mapped

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek))**

```
from sqlalchemy import *
import random

m = MetaData()

columns = [Column('a', Integer), Column('b', Integer), Column('c', Integer)]
uq = UniqueConstraint(columns[0], 'b', 'c')

random.shuffle(columns)
t = Table('t', m, *(columns + [uq]))

```

based on the order of columns, the attach event associated with "a" will prematurely cause the constraint to initialize itself before the table is set up.

The original case arises due to a declarative mapping that combines column objects with string names, and the ordering changes due to changes in declared_attr:

```
class Foo(object):

    foo = Column(Unicode(64), nullable=False)

    @declared_attr
    def bar(cls):
        return Column("bar", Integer)


class ItemCategory(Base, Foo):
    __tablename__ = 'item_category'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = Column(Unicode(64), nullable=False)

    __table_args__ = (
        UniqueConstraint(name, "foo", "bar",
                         name='unique_category_and_parent'),)
```
